option.value: Changing Passive Voice to Active Voice - Making Active Sentences

string_table.name: npxnabnsnfns00001010011
string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To preview this video, use the Preview functionality in Storyline, republish your course using standard MP4 video, or publish to Review 360.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

slidelink.displaytext: Grammar Lesson - Active and Passive Tone
Changing Passive Voice to Active Voice
Breaking it Down with an Example

search.slidetext: changing passive voice to active voice improving your writing skills one part-of-speech at a time! next

lesson overview learning objectives identifying subjects and verbs in a sentence. determining the difference between passive and active voice. creating sentences with active voice. changing sentences from passive voice to active voice. start
creating sentences with active voice. objective 3

what makes a sentence active? creating sentences with active voice active voice clearly lets you know what is performing the action of the sentence by placing the subject at the front of the sentence. taylor played the piano.

what makes a sentence active? creating sentences with active voice. active voice clearly lets you know what is performing the action of the sentence by placing the subject at the front of the sentence. taylor played the piano. subject the person, place, or thing performing the action. verb the action being done in the sentence, usually by the subject. object something in the sentence that is being acted on by the subject.

what makes a sentence active? creating sentences with active voice. taylor played the piano. the above sentence lets you know… what action is taking place (verb) who is doing the action (subject) what is receiving the action (object) active voice clearly lets you know what is performing the action of the sentence by placing the subject at the front of the sentence. source picture from articulate 360 media library; sound effect from pixabay

try again try again try again try again try again try again review the previous slides and try again. incorrect continue continue continue continue continue continue almost there! check to make sure your subject is performing the action, or verb, of the sentence. remember that the subject is the superstar of the sentence, not an object with a period in it! incorrect continue continue continue continue continue continue that's right! that sentence is in the active voice. correct make an active sentences by moving the appropriate words from the word bank to the dotted boxes. make sure that the words are in proper grammatical order! hint: notice what words have punctuation at the end of them. there are some trick words, so watch out! check your understanding creating sentences with active voice walked my dog. by was robin sentence 1 word bank

step 3. finally, you’d make sure to place them in order starting with the subject to make it as clear as possible! step 2. then you would identify what is receiving the action of the verb. that will be the object. step 2. then you would identify what is receiving the action of the verb. that will be the object. what makes a sentence active? creating sentences with active voice. to make an active sentence, focus on what the subject is doing. for example, if you want to make a sentence on the affect of music on user engagement… step 1. first, identify the verb to know what is performing the verb’s action.that will be your subject.

step 3. music increased user engagement! step 2. object = user engagement step 2. object = user engagement what makes a sentence active? creating sentences with active voice. to make an active sentence, focus on what the subject is doing. for example, if you want to make a sentence on how user engagement is increased by music… step 1. verb = increasedsubject = music

what makes a sentence active? creating sentences with active voice. to make an active sentence, focus on what the subject is doing. for example, if you want to make a sentence on the affect of music on user engagement… music increased user engagement. now that’s a good, clear active sentence!
time to practice creating sentences with active voice. let’s go!

incorrect make sure to move the words around. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue active sentences! time to make unscramble the words, and type the sentence they make below!

incorrect incorrect. there are some extra, tricky words included. the subject should be at the front of the sentence and performing the action, or verb. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect incorrect. there are some extra, tricky words included. the subject should be at the front of the sentence and performing the action, or verb. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you made an active sentence! continue continue continue continue continue continue billy by was loved the dogs make an active sentence from the words below!

incorrect incorrect. there are some extra, tricky words included. the subject should be at the front of the sentence and performing the action, or verb. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect incorrect. there are some extra, tricky words included. the subject should be at the front of the sentence and performing the action, or verb. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you made an active sentence! continue continue continue continue continue continue make an active sentence from the words below! the grandma by was called the house

incorrect incorrect. there are some extra, tricky words included. the subject should be at the front of the sentence and performing the action, or verb. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect incorrect. there are some extra, tricky words included. the subject should be at the front of the sentence and performing the action, or verb. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you made an active sentence! continue continue continue continue continue continue make an active sentence from the words below! the sound by was came from the clouds

incorrect incorrect. there are some extra, tricky words included. the subject should be at the front of the sentence and performing the action, or verb. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect incorrect. there are some extra, tricky words included. the subject should be at the front of the sentence and performing the action, or verb. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you made an active sentence! continue continue continue continue continue continue make an active sentence from the words below! the pots by were cooks paid for

incorrect incorrect. there are some extra, tricky words included. the subject should be at the front of the sentence and performing the action, or verb. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect incorrect. there are some extra, tricky words included. the subject should be at the front of the sentence and performing the action, or verb. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you made an active sentence! continue continue continue continue continue continue make an active sentence from the words below! the athlete by was the game played

incorrect make sure to move the words around. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! let’s see those results. continue continue continue continue continue continue the results! time to see unscramble the words, and type the sentence they make below!

terms.term: Active voice clearly lets you know WHAT is performing the action of the sentence by placing the SUBJECT at the front of the sentence.
Something in the sentence that is being acted on by the subject.
Passive voice is a sentence arranged to make the SUBJECT receive action, rather than the OBJECT.
The person, place, or thing performing the action.
The action being done in the sentence, usually by the subject.
